title: Who's running in the Paris mayoral election?
subhead: Six main candidates are vying to succeed Mayor Anne Hidalgo, who is not running for re-election, in the municipal elections on March 15 and 22.

title: US Senate passes deal expected to shorten shutdown
US Justice Department releases millions of new pages of Epstein files
Zaki Laïdi, political scientist: 'In 2025, building spheres of influence is infinitely more difficult than during the Cold War'
subhead: While the theory of spheres of influence is highly popular, four factors counterbalance it, writes the international systems expert in an op-ed for Le Monde. He describes a hybrid world order, where Sino-American bipolarization and the rise of the Global South collide.

title: Pieter Mulier leaves Maison Alaïa
subhead: The Richemont Group label announced on Friday, January 30, that its artistic director, who had held the position since 2021, is stepping down. He will present his final collection during Paris Fashion Week at the beginning of March.

title: In Svalbard, where sea ice is vanishing faster than anywhere else, polar bears remain healthy
subhead: The bears have not lost weight over the past 20 years in the Norwegian archipelago, despite the region's accelerating warming. Among the reasons: They hunt prey other than seals, such as reindeer and birds.

title: 'Facing Trump, Europe, Canada and Latin America have to navigate between misalignment, non-alignment and avoidance'
subhead: The sweeping powers that the US president has granted himself through his Board of Peace serve only to discourage even the best intentions, observes Le Monde's columnist Gilles Paris.

'The only thing left to do is leave': Cuba pushed to the brink
subhead: 'Cuba, an island adrift' (2/3). Since the wave of unrest that swept the country in 2021, more than two million Cubans have fled. Those who remain on the island scrape by with varying degrees of success, as the exorbitant price of basic goods has become a source of inequality between those with nothing and those with access to foreign currency.

title: Yuri Dmitriev, the Russian historian imprisoned for denouncing Kremlin attempts to rewrite history
subhead: Detained in a penal colony in Mordovia, the 70-year-old historian, who specializes in the Stalin regime's crimes, is one of Russia's oldest political prisoners. His crime? Refusing to accept historical falsifications that the Kremlin aims to impose on public opinion.

title: Iran in collective shock after bloody crackdown
subhead: Even though internet access remains mostly cut off, a few openings have allowed the population to grasp the unprecedented violence unleashed on protesters: tens of thousands killed, mass arrests, hospitals under surveillance and overcrowded prisons.
